articles.headline: PG&E Pleads Guilty to 84 Counts of Manslaughter in Camp Fire Case
articles.snippet: The California utility’s transmission line started the 2018 fire that killed dozens and destroyed the town of Paradise.
articles.abstract: The California utility’s transmission line started the 2018 fire that killed dozens and destroyed the town of Paradise.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a nearly empty courtroom on Tuesday, the chief executive of Pacific Gas & Electric stood in front of a judge and said the same three words more than 80 times: “Guilty, your honor.”
articles.byline: By Ivan Penn and Peter Eavis

articles.headline: Trump Administration Sues to Try to Delay Publication of Bolton’s Book
articles.snippet: The request comes a week before the highly anticipated memoir was set to be published.
articles.abstract: The request comes a week before the highly anticipated memoir was set to be published.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Trump administration sued the former national security adviser John R. Bolton on Tuesday to try to delay publication of his highly anticipated memoir about his time in the White House, saying the book contained classified information that would compromise national security if it became public.
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman and Katie Benner

articles.headline: Reconsidering the Past, One Statue at a Time
articles.snippet: From Virginia to New Mexico, protests over police brutality have brought hundreds of years of American history bubbling to the surface.
articles.abstract: From Virginia to New Mexico, protests over police brutality have brought hundreds of years of American history bubbling to the surface.
articles.lead_paragraph: The boiling anger that exploded in the days after George Floyd gasped his final breaths is now fueling a national movement to topple perceived symbols of racism and oppression in the United States, as protests over police brutality against African-Americans expand to include demands for a more honest accounting of American history.
articles.byline: By Sarah Mervosh, Simon Romero and Lucy Tompkins

articles.headline: The Tech I.P.O. Comes Roaring Back in the Pandemic
articles.snippet: Now that the stock market has largely shrugged off the coronavirus, start-ups are scrambling to go public.
articles.abstract: Now that the stock market has largely shrugged off the coronavirus, start-ups are scrambling to go public.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — As the coronavirus spread in March, Vroom, a start-up that sells used vehicles online, shelved its plans to go public and rushed to shore up its operations.

articles.headline: 7 Lessons (and Warnings) From Those Who Marched With Dr. King
articles.snippet: The tumult and passion of the past weeks have left the surviving veterans of the civil rights era with trepidation and hope.
articles.abstract: The tumult and passion of the past weeks have left the surviving veterans of the civil rights era with trepidation and hope.
articles.lead_paragraph: Throughout the past several weeks, as protests over the killing of George Floyd rippled through America’s cities, a 79-year-old retired schoolteacher has spent her days watching the news in her home in Albany, Ga., sometimes with tears running down her face.

articles.headline: China Is Collecting DNA From Tens of Millions of Men and Boys, Using U.S. Equipment
articles.snippet: Even children are pressed into giving blood samples to build a sweeping genetic database that will add to Beijing’s growing surveillance capabilities, raising questions about abuse and privacy.
articles.abstract: Even children are pressed into giving blood samples to build a sweeping genetic database that will add to Beijing’s growing surveillance capabilities, raising questions about abuse and privacy.
articles.lead_paragraph: The police in China are collecting blood samples from men and boys from across the country to build a genetic map of its roughly 700 million males, giving the authorities a powerful new tool for their emerging high-tech surveillance state.

articles.headline: Beijing’s Partial Lockdown a Sign of the World’s New Normal
articles.snippet: China’s capital canceled flights and shut schools as a new coronavirus outbreak raised fears of a broader contagion. The city’s experience points to what other countries including the United States face as they reopen their economies.
articles.abstract: China’s capital canceled flights and shut schools as a new coronavirus outbreak raised fears of a broader contagion. The city’s experience points to what other countries including the United States face as they reopen their economies.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Chinese economy had been firing back up. Travelers had been returning to fill trains and planes. Communist Party leaders had been celebrating their success in defeating the coronavirus.
articles.byline: By Chris Buckley and Keith Bradsher

articles.headline: Aunt Jemima Brand to Change Name and Image Over ‘Racial Stereotype’
articles.snippet: Quaker Oats, the owner of the 131-year-old brand, said it would retire the name as it worked “to make progress toward racial equality.”
articles.abstract: Quaker Oats, the owner of the 131-year-old brand, said it would retire the name as it worked “to make progress toward racial equality.”
articles.lead_paragraph: For decades, Quaker Oats knew that one of its major brands, Aunt Jemima, was built on racist imagery. The company inched toward fixing the problem over the years, replacing the kerchief on the Aunt Jemima character’s head with a plaid headband in 1968, and adding pearl earrings and a lace collar in 1989. But it was not until Wednesday that Quaker Oats announced it would drop the Aunt Jemima name and change the packaging.
